verses.text: Do no evil, and evil will not overtake you.
verses.comment: The opening verse sets an ethical foundation consistent with wisdom literature in the Hebrew Scriptures, emphasizing moral choices.

verses.text: Stay away from wrongdoing, and it will turn aside from you.
verses.comment: The active avoidance of evil as a path of life relates to teachings throughout Proverbs, highlighting moral responsibility.

verses.text: Do not sow in the furrows of injustice, and you will not reap a double harvest of it.
verses.comment: The agricultural metaphor underlines the biblical principle of sowing and reaping: evil actions return multiplied consequences.

verses.text: Do not seek authority from the Lord or a place of honor from the king.
verses.comment: Scripture warns against ambition for position rather than humble service, with implications for spiritual leadership.

verses.text: Do not justify yourself before God, for he knows your heart; do not seek to impress the judge.
verses.comment: Human righteousness falls short before God's perfect knowledge. Spiritual humility is essential for all believers.

verses.text: Do not desire to be seen as righteous before the community, and do not flaunt your wisdom before the elders.
verses.comment: Echoes warnings against hypocrisy and seeking public praise for religious or moral deeds.

verses.text: Do not seek the position of judge, lest you be unable to overcome injustice, nor should you show partiality, or you may stumble.
verses.comment: This broadens the responsibility of leadership to impartiality, which is central in biblical law and teaching.

verses.text: Do not commit a sin twice; even for one, you will not go unpunished.
verses.comment: The persistent sinner faces judgment. The text subtly hints at the need for confession and true repentance.

verses.text: Do not say, 'God will look upon the multitude of my offerings; when I present them to the Most High, he will accept them.'
verses.comment: External religious actions alone do not bring favor with God; proper repentance and a contrite heart are necessary.

verses.text: Do not be fainthearted in your prayer, nor neglect to give alms.
verses.comment: Prayer and charity are foundational spiritual disciplines; this wisdom links interior devotion with outward mercy.

verses.text: Do not mock a person in bitterness of soul, for there is One who humbles and exalts.
verses.comment: This highlights God's active role in justice and mercy, echoing the Magnificat (Luke 1:52).

verses.text: Do not devise a lie against your brother, nor do the same against a friend.
verses.comment: Upholding truth is both a social and spiritual command extending from Mosaic law.

verses.text: Refuse to tell any lie, for it will not do any good.
verses.comment: The passage strongly condemns lying, a theme further developed in several New Testament letters.

verses.text: Do not speak much with foolish people, nor go with the ignorant.
verses.comment: Companionship shapes character. The wisdom tradition routinely warns against the influence of folly.

verses.text: Be cautious with the powerful, and if you approach them, beware.
verses.comment: A prudent humility is necessary when interacting with those in authority, reflecting biblical calls for wisdom and discretion.

verses.text: Do not quarrel with the rich, lest they overpower you.
verses.comment: Practical advice, recognizing the realities of social and economic power.

verses.text: Try not to offend either the poor or the desperate.
verses.comment: Compassion for the disadvantaged is a theme that finds its fulfillment in Christ's care for 'the least of these.'

verses.text: Do not despise those who are broken in spirit; give respect to the lowly.
verses.comment: Spiritual poverty is honored by God; this verse echoes the Beatitudes.

verses.text: Do not neglect the sorrow of the poor, nor turn away your face from one in need.
verses.comment: The act of mercy towards the poor is portrayed as a duty and privilege, with a spiritual reward attached.

verses.text: Do not turn away your eyes from the needy, nor give anyone reason to curse you.
verses.comment: Avoiding those in need brings negative spiritual consequence; acts of charity have strong significance.

verses.text: Do not be harsh with someone who is desperate; instead, share your bread with those who hunger.
verses.comment: Physical and spiritual sustenance are closely tied. Sharing bread recalls Christ feeding the multitudes.

verses.text: Honor your father and mother with both word and deed, so their blessing may come upon you.
verses.comment: Filial respect is foundational to biblical morality. It is intimately connected to human flourishing.

verses.text: Remember your parents even in your old age, lest you bring them grief and shame.
verses.comment: Continuity of care for parents reflects the enduring family obligations in Scripture.

verses.text: Remember that you were born through them; what can you give them in return for all they have done for you?
verses.comment: The depth of parental sacrifice points to gratitude and lifelong responsibility.

verses.text: Fear the Lord with all your soul and honor his priests; love him with all your strength.
verses.comment: Reverence for God and respect for spiritual leadership are tied tightly together, reminiscent of how obedience to faith is mediated through trusted shepherds.

verses.text: Give to him who teaches you the words of wisdom, and from your earnings, support him as you are able.
verses.comment: Material support for teaching ministry is affirmed in both Old and New Testaments, hinting at the necessity of honoring spiritual authority as a form of worship.

verses.text: With all your heart, fear the Lord; honor his servants and love them with all your strength.
verses.comment: Respect for those who serve in spiritual roles encourages unity and deep fellowship.

verses.text: Honor God and the king, and do not disobey their commands.
verses.comment: Repeated calls to obedience and respect for both divine and earthly authority, foreshadowing Christ's own submission and victory.

verses.text: Do not argue with the judge, for judgment belongs to God and rulers.
verses.comment: Respect for the judicial process is rooted in the divine order of justice, pointing to God as ultimate Judge.

verses.text: Do not be careless in giving to the poor, nor show disfavor to those in need.
verses.comment: Generosity as a spiritual act is reinforced by this and many passages in both Testaments.

verses.text: Stretch out your hand to the poor, so your blessing may be perfect.
verses.comment: Perfect blessing is connected with wholehearted generosity. This has both literal and spiritual implications.

verses.text: Let your gifts reach all the living, and do not withhold kindness from the dead.
verses.comment: The obligation of kindness extends even to the dead, echoing acts of mercy and memorial traditions.

verses.text: Do good to the living, and give honor to the dead.
verses.comment: Respect and care for the dead is a recurring biblical theme and dramatizes the dignity of every person.

verses.text: Do not avoid those who weep, but mourn with them.
verses.comment: Compassion is multidimensional—physical, emotional, and spiritual. It is exemplified in Christ's ministry.

verses.text: Do not neglect to visit the sick, for by such acts you will be loved.
verses.comment: Ministry to the suffering foreshadows later spiritual practices and community care.

verses.text: In all you do, remember your end, and you will never sin.
verses.comment: Contemplating one's final destiny instills humility and wisdom. The text reflects a call to ongoing conversion and perseverance in virtue.
